specimen.util package

Submodules

specimen.util.cobra_models module

Utility functions & Co. for handling cobra models.

specimen.util.cobra_models.are_compartment_names_valid(model)

Checks if the compartments of a model are valid.

Note: Valid means their keys are part of VALID_COMPARTMENTS.

Parameters:

model (cobra.Model) – A model.

Returns:

Result of the test. True if names are valid.

Return type:

bool

specimen.util.cobra_models.build_core_pan_model(file_list, based_on='id', remove_genes=True)

From a list of file paths to models, create a core-pan model from their reactions.

The core-pan model is created by merging all reactions of the models into one model. Reactions that are found in all models are characterised as ‘core’, while the others are characterised as ‘pan’. This characterisation is saved in the notes-field unter ‘core-pan’.

Note:

To make the final model ‘cleaner’, each model is checked for their compartment names using resolve_compartment_names().

Matching of the reactions can be based on:

‘id’ : use the reaction id for comparison

Parameters:

  • file_list (list) – List of file paths to GEMs.

  • based_on (string) – Option on how to define reactions as equal. Default is ‘id’, all options can be found in the function description.

  • remove_genes (bool) – Option to remove the genes / gene reaction rules from the model. Default is True, as the core-pan differentiation is based on ID and therefore on the reactions.

Returns:

The core-pan model.

Return type:

cobra.Model

specimen.util.cobra_models.compare_to_core_pan(model, cp_model, based_on='id')

Perform a pan-core model analysis by comparing an input model and a pan-core model.

Currently only checks the reactions. Depends highly on the pan-core model being build with build_core_pan_model().

Matching/Comparison can be based on:

‘id’ : use the reaction id for comparison

@TODO

  • implements more options for comparison

  • include checking for metabolites

Parameters:

  • model (cobra.Model) – The model to perform the analysis on.

  • cp_model (cobra.Model) – The pan-core model to compare to.

  • based_on (string) – Option on how to define reactions as equal. Default is ‘id’, all options can be found in the function description.

Returns:

A report of the comparison.

Return type:

report.PanCoreAnalysisReport

specimen.util.cobra_models.define_core_pan_reactions(reac_list, core, pan, based_on='id')

Given three lists of new reactions, core reaction and pan reactions, sort the reactions of the first list into the latter two.

Matching of the reactions can be based on:

‘id’ : use the reaction id for comparison

Parameters:

  • reac_list (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – The list of new reactions.

  • core (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – The list of core reactions.

  • pan (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – The list of pan reactions.

  • based_on (string) – Option on how to define reactions as equal. Default is ‘id’, all options can be found in the function description.

Returns:

The updated lists of core and pan reactions.

Return type:

tuple, (core,pan)

specimen.util.cobra_models.find_growth_obj_func(model)

Get the ID of the growth function of the model.

Uses a list of standart names to search for a match and returns the first one. If no match is found, uses the objective expression instead.

Parameters:

model (cobra.Model) – The model.

Returns:

The ID of the reaction identified/set as the growth.

Return type:

string

specimen.util.cobra_models.generate_statistics(model)
specimen.util.cobra_models.get_intersecting_reactions(reacA, reacB, based_on='id')

From two lists of reactions, get the intersection. If reactions are determined the same, the reaction object from the first reaction list is taken for the output list.

The intersection can be done based on:

‘id’ : use the reaction id for comparison

Parameters:

  • reacA (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions.

  • reacB (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – Another list of reactions.

  • based_on (string) – Option on how to define reactions as equal. Default is ‘id’, all options can be found in the function description.

Raises:

ValueError: Unknown option for intersection based_on.

Returns:

The intersection of the two lists.

Return type:

list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction

specimen.util.cobra_models.get_unique_reactions(reacA, reacB, based_on='id')

From two lists of reactions, get the unique reactions of the first list.

Unique reactions are determined by comparing:

‘id’ : use the reaction id for comparison

Parameters:

  • reacA (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions.

  • reacB (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – Another list of reactions.

  • based_on (string) – Option on how to define reactions as equal. Default is ‘id’, all options can be found in the function description.

Raises:

ValueError: Unknown option for based_on.

Returns:

The reactions of list A that are not in list B.

Return type:

list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction

specimen.util.cobra_models.reannotate_sbo_memote(model)

Remap the very specific SBO terms from SBOannotator to the high-level ones used by memote. Directly changes the model annotations.

Parameters:

model (cobra.Model) – The model to be reannotated.

Returns:

The reannotated model

Return type:

cobra.Model

specimen.util.cobra_models.remove_duplicate_reactions(reac, based_on='id')

From a list of reactions, remove the duplicate reactions.

Duplicate reactions are determined by comparing:

‘id’ : use the reaction id for comparison

Parameters:

  • reacA (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions.

  • reacB (list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction) – Another list of reactions.

  • based_on (string) – Option on how to define reactions as equal. Default is ‘id’, all options can be found in the function description.

Raises:

ValueError: Unknown option for based_on.

Returns:

The reactions of list A that are not in list B.

Return type:

list, list elements should be cobra.Reaction

specimen.util.cobra_models.resolve_compartment_names(model)

Try to resolve invalid compartment names for a given model.

Note: Valid means their keys are part of VALID_COMPARTMENTS. Valid mappings for solving the problem are in COMP_MAPPING.

Parameters:

model (cobra.Model) – A model.

Raises:

KeyError: Unknown compartment detected. Cannot resolve problem.

Returns:

The updated model if possible

Return type:

cobra.Model

specimen.util.io module

Classes to import, handle, manipulate and save different objects etc.

specimen.util.io.kegg_reaction_parser(rn_id)

Get the KEGG reaction entry for a KEGG reaction ID and parse it to retrieve information in form of a dictionary.

Parameters:

rn_id (string) – The KEGG reaction ID that shall be retrived and parsed.

Returns:

Information about name, equationand database links of the entry (reaction).

Return type:

dict, keys include ‘name’,’db’,’rc’ and ‘equation’

specimen.util.io.read_model_cobra(path: str)

Reads in a model, depending on the given file type.

Parameters:

path (string) – Path to the model.

Raises:

ValueError: Unknown file extension for model.

Returns:

The model read in with cobra.

Return type:

cobra.Model

specimen.util.set_up module

Collection of functions for setting up the environment for the pipeline.

specimen.util.set_up.build_data_directories(dir, chunk_size=2048)

Set up the directory structure for the data and download the files from MetaNetX and BiGG.

Parameters:

  • dir (string) – Parent folder to write the subfolder structure to.

  • chunk_size (int) – Size of the chunks of data while downloading. Default is 2048. Only used for downloading the MetaNetX files.

specimen.util.set_up.dict_recursive_check(dictA, key=None)

Function to check if a configuration is valid to run the pipeline.

Parameters:

  • dictA (dict or other) – Current dictionary or value to be validated.

  • key (string) – key of dictA, if it was an entry of a dictionary. Default is None.

specimen.util.set_up.dict_recursive_combine(dictA, dictB)

Helper-function to combine two configuration file.

specimen.util.set_up.download_bigg(dir='BiGG-namespace')

Download the BiGG namespace files and rewrite them into the format needed for the workflow.

Parameters:

dir (string) – Name of the directory to write the files into.

specimen.util.set_up.download_config(filename='./my_basic_config.yaml', type='basic')

Load a configuration file from the package and save a copy for the user to edit.

Depending on the knowledge of the user, either a ‘basic’ or an ‘advanced’ type of configuration file can be downloaded.

Parameters:

  • filename (string) – Filename/filepath to save the downloaded config file under.

  • type (string) – The type of file to download. Can either be ‘basic’ or ‘advanced’. Default is ‘basic’.

Raises:

ValueError: ‘Unknown type of config file detected’

specimen.util.set_up.download_mnx(dir='MetaNetX/', chunk_size=1024)

Download the data needed from the MetaNetX database.

Parameters:

  • dir (string, should end with '/'.) – Directory to write the diwnloaded files to.

  • chunk_size (int) – Size of the chunk of data that is loaded into memory during download. Default is 1024.

specimen.util.set_up.validate_config(userc)

Validate a user config file for use in the pipeline.

Note: currently not everything is checked, mainly the needed files are.

Parameters:

userc (string) – Path to the user configuration file.

Raise:
FileNotFoundError:

Directory set for config:data:data:direc does not exist.

Returns:

The validated, read-in configuration file.

Return type:

dict, nested (read-in yaml file)

specimen.util.util module

specimen.util.util.create_DIAMOND_db_from_folder(dir, out, name='database', extension='faa', threads=2)

Build a DIAMOND database from a folder containing FASTA files.

Parameters:

  • dir (string, required) – Path to the directory to search for FASTA files for the database (recursive file search).

  • out (string, required) – Path of the directory of the output.

  • name (string, optional) – Name of the created database. Default is ‘database’.

  • extension (string, optional) – File extension of the FASTA files (to determine which files to search for). Default is ‘faa’.

  • threads (int, optional) – Number of threads to use for DIAMOND. Default is 2

specimen.util.util.create_NCBIinfo_mapping(dir, out, extension='gbff')

Create a NCBI information mapping file from a folder containing e.g. gbff files.

Parameters:

  • dir (string) – Path to the directory for the recursive file search for the mapping.

  • out (string) – Path of the directory for the output.

  • extension (string) – Name of the file extension to be searched. Default is gbff, and currently it is advised to leave it at that.

specimen.util.util.get_info_GenBank_Record(file_path)

Retrieves a table containg information about the following qualifiers from a Genbank file: [‘protein_id’,’locus_tag’,’db_xref’,’old_locus_tag’,’EC_number’].

Parameters:

file_path (str) – Path to the Genbank (.gbff) file.

Returns:

A table containing the information above.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame, columns= [‘ncbi_accession_version’, ‘locus_tag_ref’,’old_locus_tag’,’GeneID’,’EC number’]

specimen.util.util.rewrite_metabolites(file, out)

Rewrites or reformates a given BiGG metabolites namespace TXT file to the following columns: bigg_id, name, reaction_string, EC number, BioCyc, MetaNetX (MNX) Equation, SEED Reaction

Parameters:

  • file (string) – Path of the input file.

  • out (string) – Path of the output file.

specimen.util.util.rewrite_reactions(file, out)

Rewrites or reformates a given BiGG reaction namespace TXT file to the following columns: bigg_id, name, reaction_string, EC number, BioCyc, MetaNetX (MNX) Equation, SEED Reaction

Parameters:

  • file (string) – Path of the input file.

  • out (string) – Path of the output file.

specimen.util.util.separate_db_links_metabolite(row)

Separate the database links in the column of the same name from a metabolite BiGG namespace file row.

Parameters:

row (pandas object, a pd.DataFrame row) – one row of the table

Returns:

The row with new columns for certain database links (CHEBI, BioCyc, KEGG, MNX, SEED, InChI)

Return type:

pandas object, a pd.DataFrame row

specimen.util.util.separate_db_links_reaction(row)

Separate the database links in the column of the same name from a reaction BiGG namespace file row.

Parameters:

row (pandas object, a pd.DataFrame row) – one row of the table

Returns:

The row with new columns for certain database links (EC number, BioCyc, KEGG, MNX, SEED)

Return type:

pandas object, a pd.DataFrame row

specimen.util.util.write_BiGG_namespace_to_table(input, out=None, type='reactions')

Rewrite a BiGG namespace into a table format.

Parameters:

  • input (string) – The input BiGG namespace txt-file (its path). Can be for reactions or metabolites.

  • out (string) – Path to the output file. Default is the name of the input file with the additional tag ‘_rewritte’.

  • type (string) – Specifies if the input file is for reactions or metabolites. Can either be ‘reactions’ (default) or ‘metabolites’.
